name: Ralph Lauren
title: How apparel brands aim to win the spotlight at the Winter Olympics
description:
Compared to the Summer Olympics, the Winter Olympics are typically smaller, largely due to high infrastructure costs and climate restraints.
In fact, partnerships tend to lead to sales; Anta reported a rise in revenue when sponsoring the 2022 Winter Olympics in Beijing.
This year, NBC said ad slots for the Winter Olympics sold out with “unprecedented demand,” luring more than 100 new advertisers.
The city is also home to Milan Fashion Week, as well as the fashion district Quadrilatero della Moda.
Functional fabrications For all the hype around fashion at the Olympics, brands are still prioritizing fit, fabric and functionality.
text:
The Winter Olympics and Paralympics will take place from Feb. 6-22 in Milan and Cortina d’Ampezzo. Compared to the Summer Olympics, the Winter Olympics are typically smaller, largely due to high infrastructure costs and climate restraints. Around 2,900 athletes will compete in 2026, compared to 10,500 athletes in 2024. But the merchandise and marketing opportunities for brands are still massive, considering the buzz around sports, the billions of viewers and the allure of a “Big Four” city like Milan. In fact, partnerships tend to lead to sales; Anta reported a rise in revenue when sponsoring the 2022 Winter Olympics in Beijing. This year, NBC said ad slots for the Winter Olympics sold out with “unprecedented demand,” luring more than 100 new advertisers.

“The Olympics are, hands down, one of the most powerful sports platforms in the world,” Harry Poole, svp at the marketing agency Excel Sports Management, told Modern Retail. Poole started his career representing Olympic athletes before shifting to the marketing side. “When you think about global connectivity and cultural relevance, [the Olympics] is a movement that inspires generations,” Poole said. “And the market for it this year is fantastic, when you think about Milan and fashion and what that means to the world.”

Milan is known for its luxury houses like Prada, its ready-to-wear styles and its quality craftsmanship, especially around leather goods. The city is also home to Milan Fashion Week, as well as the fashion district Quadrilatero della Moda. Aesthetics and design, then, play a major role in this year’s Olympics and Paralympics. For instance, this year’s official victory ceremony uniforms stemmed from a contest among three fashion design schools. The new torch design sports a sleek, minimalist look and a larger flame. Even the official motto of the Games is “IT’s your vibe.”

Fashion players, for their part, have spent months hyping up their Olympics products and partnerships. Per a December press release, Ralph Lauren’s Opening Ceremony uniform for Team U.S.A. includes a “statement winter-white wool coat,” while its Closing Ceremony uniform “draws inspiration from vintage ski racing kits.” “We look forward to … bringing our heritage of sport and style to life at the Milano Cortina Winter Olympics,” Patrice Louvet, president of Ralph Lauren, said on an earnings call in November. The company’s nine-part TikTok series around the collection and its athletes has garnered more than a quarter of a million views.

Meanwhile, Lululemon’s uniforms for Canada feature topographic map prints and maple leaf designs. The brand recently posted an Instagram video captioned, “We’re not just from Canada, we’re cut from the cold.” “All of us at Lululemon are incredibly proud to support Team Canada on the world’s largest sporting stage with product designed for athletes, and with athletes,” CEO Calvin McDonald said in a statement.

Functional fabrications

For all the hype around fashion at the Olympics, brands are still prioritizing fit, fabric and functionality. After all, wearing an eye-catching uniform at the Olympics and Paralympics is one thing. It’s another to ensure the products are optimized for performance.

Nike, which sponsors the podium for Team U.S.A., will debut its Therma-FIT Air Milano jacket at the Winter Olympics. It has called the jacket “the brand’s most technically engineered garment of its kind.” The jacket allows athletes to regulate their temperature by inflating or deflating air within compartments. “Every detail was engineered to let athletes tune their own comfort and fit,” Amie Achtymichuk, lead apparel development innovator, said in a statement.

Apparel brands are creating distinct technology for non-athletes, too, as the healthcare apparel brand Figs demonstrates. 2026 is the first Winter Olympics that Figs, known for its scrubs, will outfit members of the U.S. medical team, or the medical professionals assisting the athletes. “Our goal is really to give them a podium of their own,” Figs CEO and co-founder Trina Spear told Modern Retail.

Figs first outfitted the U.S. medical team in 2024 at the Summer Olympics in Paris. It will do so again in 2028 at the Summer Olympics in Los Angeles. But Figs had to make changes this year when it came to developing scrubs, jackets and other gear. It ended up developing a new fabrication, known as FIBREx, that’s optimized for alpine conditions like colder temperatures and wind.

“We’re really leveling up from what we did in Paris,” Spear said. “In Paris, we were mainly inside, in sporting facilities, … [but] for winter, we’re on a ski mountain. We designed and developed really warm and technical products that are also really comfortable. … You need a product that’s going to support you in a 12-hour shift or [allow you to] support an athlete across many hours.”

Meanwhile, Dagsmejan, a sleepwear company, is giving members of the Swiss National Ice Hockey Team pajamas and sleep masks to wear at night. For athletes, proper recovery, especially during sleep, is “as much a part of training as nutrition,” said Dagsmejan CEO Catarina Dahlin. Dahlin developed Dagsmejan with her husband, in consultation with partners like the Swiss Federal Laboratories for Materials Science and Technology. The company says its sleepwear uses breathable, natural fibers and focuses on temperature regulation.

As Dahlin sees it, Dagsmejan’s fabrications are perfect for helping ice hockey players wind down after a stressful day. “The matches often take place quite late, [under] very bright light and [with] high energy,” Dahlin told Modern Retail. “After that, you have to try to unwind and go to bed. But you’re also in a bed you’re not used to, and you may not be able to control the air conditioning. How well you recover really impacts how well you can perform and react when it matters.” Dagsmejan has supported the Swiss National Ice Hockey Team since 2021, and both have posted about the partnership on social media.

A lifestyle play

Not all fashion companies involved with the Olympics are developing technical fabrics for those on the ground in Italy. Companies can activate around the events in multiple ways, including through licensing agreements for gear like hats and sweatshirts. These items allow fans of teams and events to show their spirit — and they help boost sales for brands, too.

Some fashion brands are focusing more on the consumer angle. Chubbies, which makes swim trunks and board shorts, rolled out a lifestyle collection for fans to wear at home. The line — which includes performance polos, hoodies and lined swim trunks — is part of a licensing agreement with Team U.S.A.

Team U.S.A. gave Chubbies design guidelines, but the brand could still present its point of view, Tyde Kaneshiro, senior product manager of special projects at Chubbies, told Modern Retail. Chubbies ended up developing a print modeled after intricate snowflake photography. “In a lot of our seasonal development, we look to the runway for trend and color inspiration,” said Kevin Dopp, Chubbies’s senior design director. “But, in this particular [case], we looked at art as inspiration.”

The final designs have red, white and blue to reflect the colors of Team U.S.A. “It doesn’t look generic and feels very us,” Kaneshiro said. The brand is pairing the pieces with a humorous marketing campaign. An Instagram video shows a model in a studio, pretending to ski, while getting “fake snow thrown at him” from a fan, said Ashley Spencer, director of marketing at Chubbies. “We’re championing the vibe of the Olympics in a Chubbies-spun way,” she added.

Also in January, J.Crew rolled out a lifestyle collection with U.S. Ski & Snowboard as part of a partnership that will last three years. The pieces include knitwear, shirts and accessories for women, men and kids. “Our inaugural collection underscores J.Crew’s ability to connect timeless American style with the cultural significance of sport on a global stage,” chairman Kevin Ulrich said in a statement. J.Crew’s marketing campaign around the collection features pro athletes throwing snowballs and relaxing on chaise lounges.

Meanwhile, Skims released the fourth iteration of its official Team U.S.A. capsule, complete with loungewear, sleepwear and intimates. Per Skims, the collection has “rest and recovery in mind” and features “graphics that take their cues from team uniforms.” “It’s comfortable, functional and captures the pride I feel in representing Team U.S.A.,” Olympian Madison Chock said in a statement.

name: Philips
title: A $400000 payout after Maduro's capture is putting prediction markets in the spotlight
description:
Here's what we know: How prediction markets work The scope of topics involved in prediction markets can range immensely — from escalation in geopolitical conflicts, to pop culture moments and even the fate of conspiracy theories.
Proponents of prediction markets argue putting money on the line leads to better forecasts.
Still, it's never a “crystal ball,” he noted, and prediction markets can be wrong, too.
Loose regulation Because they’re positioned as selling event contracts, prediction markets are regulated by the CFTC.
On Friday, Democratic Rep. Ritchie Torres introduced a bill aimed at curbing government employees involvement in politically-related event contracts.
text:
Prediction markets let people wager on anything from a basketball game to the outcome of a presidential election — and recently, the downfall of former Venezuelan President Nicolás Maduro.

The latter is drawing renewed scrutiny into this murky world of speculative, 24/7 transactions. Last week, an anonymous trader pocketed more than $400,000 after betting that Maduro would soon be out of office.

The bulk of the trader’s bids on the platform Polymarket were made mere hours before President Donald Trump announced the surprise nighttime raid that led to Maduro’s capture, fueling online suspicions of potential insider trading because of the timing of the wagers and the trader’s narrow activity on the platform. Others argued that the risk of getting caught was too big, and that previous speculation about Maduro’s future could have led to such transactions.

Polymarket did not respond to requests for comment.

The commercial use of prediction markets has skyrocketed in recent years, opening the door for people to wage their money on the likelihood of a growing list of future events. But despite some eye-catching windfalls, traders still lose money everyday. And in terms of government oversight in the U.S., the trades are categorized differently than traditional forms of gambling — raising questions about transparency and risk.

Here's what we know:

How prediction markets work

The scope of topics involved in prediction markets can range immensely — from escalation in geopolitical conflicts, to pop culture moments and even the fate of conspiracy theories. Recently, there’s been a surge of wages on elections and sports games. But some users have also bet millions on things like a rumored — and ultimately unrealized — “secret finale” for the Netflix’s “Stranger Things,” whether the U.S. government will confirm the existence of extraterrestrial life and how much billionaire Elon Musk might post on social media this month.

In industry-speak, what someone buys or sells in a prediction market is called an “event contract.” They're typically advertised as “yes” or “no” wagers. And the price of one fluctuates between $0 and $1, reflecting what traders are collectively willing to pay based on a 0% to 100% chance of whether they think an event will occur.

The more likely traders think an event will occur, the more expensive that contract will become. And as those odds change over time, users can cash out early to make incremental profits, or try to avoid higher losses on what they’ve already invested.

Proponents of prediction markets argue putting money on the line leads to better forecasts. Experts like Koleman Strumpf, an economics professor at Wake Forest University, think there’s value in monitoring these platforms for potential news — pointing to prediction markets’ past success with some election outcomes, including the 2024 presidential race.

Still, it's never a “crystal ball,” he noted, and prediction markets can be wrong, too.

Who is behind all of the trading is also pretty murky. While the companies running the platforms collect personal information of their users in order to verify identities and payments, most people can trade under anonymous pseudonyms online — making it difficult for the public to know who is profiting off many event contracts. In theory, people investing their money may be closely following certain events, but others could just be randomly guessing.

Critics stress that the ease and speed of joining these 24/7 wagers leads to financial losses everyday, particularly harming users who may already struggle with gambling. The space also broadens possibilities for potential insider trading.

The major players

Polymarket is one of the largest prediction markets in the world, where its users can fund event contracts through cryptocurrency, debit or credit cards and bank transfers.

Restrictions vary by country, but in the U.S., the reach of these markets has expanded rapidly over recent years, coinciding with shifting policies out of Washington. Former President Joe Biden was aggressive in cracking down on prediction markets and following a 2022 settlement with the Commodity Futures Trading Commission, Polymarket was barred from operating in the country.

That changed under Trump late last year, when Polymarket announced it would be returning to the U.S. after receiving clearance from the commission. American-based users can now join a platform “waitlist.”

Meanwhile, Polymarket’s top competitor, Kalshi, has been a federally-regulated exchange since 2020. The platform offers similar ways to buy and sell event contracts as Polymarket — and it currently allows event contracts on elections and sports nationwide. Kalshi won court approval just weeks before the 2024 election to let Americans put money on upcoming political races and began to host sports trading about a year ago.

The space is now crowded with other big names. Sports betting giants DraftKings and FanDuel both launched prediction platforms last month. Online broker Robinhood is widening its own offerings. Trump’s social media site Truth Social has also promised to offer an in-platform prediction market through a partnership with Crypto.com — and one of the president’s sons, Donald Trump Jr., holds advisory roles at both Polymarket and Kalshi.

“The train has left the station on these event contracts, they’re not going away,” said Melinda Roth, a visiting associate professor at Washington and Lee University’s School of Law.

Loose regulation

Because they’re positioned as selling event contracts, prediction markets are regulated by the CFTC. That means they can avoid state-level restrictions or bans in place for traditional gambling and sports betting today.

“It’s a huge loophole,” said Karl Lockhart, an assistant professor of law at DePaul University who has studied this space. “You just have to comply with one set of regulations, rather than (rules from) each state around the country.”

Sports betting is taking center stage. There are a handful of big states — like California and Texas, for example — where sports betting is still illegal, but people can now wager on games, athlete trades and more through event contracts.

A growing number of states and tribes are suing to stop this. And lawyers expect litigation to eventually reach the U.S. Supreme Court, as added regulations from the Trump administration seem unlikely.

Federal law bars event contracts related to gaming as well as war, terrorism and assassinations, Roth said, which could put some prediction market trades on shaky ground, at least in the U.S. But users might still find ways to buy certain contracts while traveling abroad or connecting to different VPNs.

Whether the CFTC will take any of that on has yet to be seen. But the agency, which did not respond to request for comment, has already taken steps away from enforcement.

Despite overseeing trillions of dollars for the overall U.S. derivatives market, the CFTC is also much smaller than the Securities and Exchange Commission. And at the same time event contracts are growing rapidly on prediction market platforms, there have been additional cuts to the CFTC's workforce and a wave of leadership departures under Trump's second term. Only one of five commissioner slots operating the agency is currently filled.

Still, other lawmakers calling for a stronger crack down on potential insider trading in prediction markets — particularly following suspicion around last week’s Maduro trade on Polymarket. On Friday, Democratic Rep. Ritchie Torres introduced a bill aimed at curbing government employees involvement in politically-related event contracts.

The bill has already gotten support from Kalshi CEO Tarek Mansour — who on LinkedIn maintained that insider trading has always been banned on his company's platform but that more needs to be done to crack down on unregulated prediction markets.

name: Stolt Nielsen
title: Niels G. Stolt-Nielsen
description:
Niels G. Stolt-Nielsen is a Norwegian business executive serving as Chairman of the Board of Directors at Stolt-Nielsen Limited, a global transportation and logistics company specializing in chemicals, gases, and aquaculture, since September 2023.
He is the son of Jacob Stolt-Nielsen (1931–2015), who founded Stolt-Nielsen Limited in 1959 as a pioneering venture in specialized shipping.
[4] Academic pursuits Niels G. Stolt-Nielsen pursued his higher education in the United States, enrolling at Hofstra University in Hempstead, New York.
[4] Career at Stolt-Nielsen Limited Initial roles and international expansion Niels G. Stolt-Nielsen joined Stolt-Nielsen Limited in 1990, immediately after graduating from Hofstra University with a BS in Business and Finance, beginning his career as a shipbroker at the company's office in Greenwich, Connecticut.
[7] CEO leadership and strategic shifts Niels G. Stolt-Nielsen assumed the position of Chief Executive Officer of Stolt-Nielsen Limited in November 2000, succeeding his father, Jacob Stolt-Nielsen, who had led the company since its founding in 1959.
text:
Niels G. Stolt-Nielsen is a Norwegian business executive serving as Chairman of the Board of Directors at Stolt-Nielsen Limited, a global transportation and logistics company specializing in chemicals, gases, and aquaculture, since September 2023.[1] He previously held the position of Chief Executive Officer at the company from 2000 to 2023, overseeing its expansion and strategic initiatives in maritime and related sectors.[1] A graduate of Hofstra University with a BS in Business and Finance from 1990, Stolt-Nielsen joined the Stolt-Nielsen organization in 1990, initially working in Greenwich, Connecticut, before relocating to Shanghai in 1994 to establish the company's representative office there.[1] Stolt-Nielsen's career trajectory within the family-founded enterprise includes pivotal roles such as President of Stolt Sea Farm from 1996 to 2000 and Interim Chief Executive Officer of Stolt Offshore S.A. from September 2002 to March 2003, during which he navigated key operational and market challenges in the offshore energy sector.[1] Beyond Stolt-Nielsen Limited, where he has been a Director since 1996, he currently chairs the Board of Avenir LNG Limited, a joint venture focused on small-scale LNG distribution, and serves as a Director at Golar LNG Limited, a leading provider of LNG infrastructure and shipping solutions.[1][2] His leadership has been instrumental in fostering long-term value creation, including growth into sustainable energy and aquaculture ventures.[3] As a member of the Audit and Compensation Committees at Stolt-Nielsen Limited, he continues to influence governance and strategic oversight in the maritime industry.[1]

Early life and education

Family background

Niels Gregers Stolt-Nielsen was born on January 23, 1965, in Norway. He is the son of Jacob Stolt-Nielsen (1931–2015), who founded Stolt-Nielsen Limited in 1959 as a pioneering venture in specialized shipping.[4] The Stolt-Nielsen family traces its heritage to third-generation shipownership in Norway, with roots in Haugesund where Jacob grew up immersed in maritime activities, including running the family herring business as a teenager.[4] The family has played a pivotal role in global shipping, particularly through innovations in parcel tankers designed for safe transport of bulk liquids such as chemicals and edible oils, establishing industry standards without venturing into general cargo operations.[4] Raised in this influential shipping dynasty, Niels G. Stolt-Nielsen experienced early exposure to the family business environment, shaped by Norway's coastal heritage and the harbor views that inspired generations of Stolt-Nielsens. The family continues to hold a controlling interest in Stolt-Nielsen Limited, underscoring their enduring legacy in the sector.[4]

Academic pursuits

Niels G. Stolt-Nielsen pursued his higher education in the United States, enrolling at Hofstra University in Hempstead, New York. He graduated in 1990 with a Bachelor of Science (BS) degree in Business and Finance.[1][5] His choice to study in the United States, far from his native Norway, reflected the international orientation of his family's shipping legacy, providing exposure to a dynamic business environment centered in New York.[4]

Career at Stolt-Nielsen Limited

Initial roles and international expansion

Niels G. Stolt-Nielsen joined Stolt-Nielsen Limited in 1990, immediately after graduating from Hofstra University with a BS in Business and Finance, beginning his career as a shipbroker at the company's office in Greenwich, Connecticut.[1] In this initial role, he focused on chartering and brokerage activities within the bulk liquid transportation sector, leveraging his finance background to support Stolt Tankers' operations in the U.S. market.[1] By the early 1990s, Stolt-Nielsen advanced to the position of round-voyage manager, where he oversaw the planning and execution of shipping routes for chemical and product tankers, contributing to operational efficiency amid growing global trade demands. This progression highlighted his early aptitude for logistics coordination, setting the stage for broader international responsibilities.[6] In 1994, Stolt-Nielsen played a pivotal role in the company's international expansion by relocating to China to establish and lead Stolt-Nielsen Limited's first representative office in Shanghai.[1] This initiative marked a strategic entry into the Asian market, facilitating local partnerships and market intelligence for Stolt Tankers' growing presence in the region, which was undergoing rapid economic liberalization.[7] His efforts in organizing the office underscored the company's commitment to global outreach during a period of increasing demand for specialized shipping services in emerging economies. Stolt-Nielsen's contributions culminated in his appointment as a director of Stolt-Nielsen Limited in 1996, where he began overseeing initial ventures into aquaculture, including the leadership of Stolt Sea Farm as its president from 1996 to 2000.[1] This role involved directing early salmon farming operations, integrating his shipping expertise with new diversification strategies in sustainable seafood production.[6] These steps not only expanded the company's portfolio but also positioned Stolt-Nielsen as a key figure in bridging maritime logistics with innovative agribusiness.[7]

CEO leadership and strategic shifts

Niels G. Stolt-Nielsen assumed the position of Chief Executive Officer of Stolt-Nielsen Limited in November 2000, succeeding his father, Jacob Stolt-Nielsen, who had led the company since its founding in 1959.[3] Under his leadership, the company prioritized sustainable growth across its core operations in bulk-liquid logistics, including parcel tankers for chemicals and edible oils, bulk-liquid storage terminals, tank containers, and land-based aquaculture through Stolt Sea Farm.[1] This approach focused on optimizing performance, expanding asset bases, and enhancing market positions to deliver consistent financial results amid fluctuating market cycles.[8] During his tenure, Stolt-Nielsen held additional key roles that underscored his executive oversight. He served as President of Stolt Sea Farm from 1996 to 2000, guiding the aquaculture division's development prior to his CEO appointment.[1] From October 2002 to March 2003, he acted as Interim Chief Executive Officer of Stolt Offshore S.A., a subsea construction and maintenance subsidiary, during a transitional period for that business.[9] These positions highlighted his hands-on involvement in diversifying and stabilizing the group's operations beyond traditional shipping.[1] A significant strategic shift under Stolt-Nielsen's leadership was the expansion into the liquefied natural gas (LNG) and broader gas sectors, aligning with the company's expertise in liquid logistics and the global energy transition.[8] Through Stolt-Nielsen Gas, established as an investment arm during his tenure, the company acquired stakes in LNG infrastructure and shipping, including a controlling interest in Avenir LNG Limited, which operates a fleet of small-scale LNG carriers and bunkering vessels.[10] This diversification strengthened the portfolio's resilience, with investments in LNG storage terminals and related technologies contributing to long-term value creation despite market volatility in the sector.[8]

Transition to chairman

In January 2022, Niels G. Stolt-Nielsen announced his intention to step down as Chief Executive Officer of Stolt-Nielsen Limited after serving in the role since November 2000, citing the desire to introduce fresh leadership to guide the company's future.[3] He emphasized that the timing allowed the board sufficient opportunity to identify and appoint a successor while ensuring a smooth transition, reflecting his commitment to the company's ongoing success.[3] Stolt-Nielsen, who first joined the company in 1990, noted in the announcement that leading Stolt-Nielsen Limited had been a privilege, underscoring his dedication to its operations over more than three decades.[3] The succession process culminated in August 2023 with the appointment of Udo Lange as the new CEO, effective September 1, 2023.[11] Lange brought over 20 years of experience in international trade, including senior roles at FedEx Express where he led global operations in logistics and supply chain management across multiple continents.[11] This transition marked the end of Stolt-Nielsen's 23-year tenure as CEO, during which he had focused on long-term value creation in the shipping and logistics sectors.[11] Upon stepping down as CEO, Stolt-Nielsen assumed the position of Chairman of the Board of Stolt-Nielsen Limited in September 2023, subject to shareholder approval, and also joined the Audit and Compensation Committees.[1] In this new role, he continued to contribute to the company's strategic oversight, building on his extensive history since 1990 in fostering sustainable growth within the specialized shipping and related industries.[1]

Other business positions

Founding and leadership at Avance Gas

In 2007, Niels G. Stolt-Nielsen founded Avance Gas AS to enter the burgeoning market for liquefied petroleum gas (LPG) transportation, establishing it as a specialized provider of very large gas carriers (VLGCs) capable of transporting LPG across global trade routes.[12][13] Stolt-Nielsen has served as Chairman of Avance Gas since its inception, steering the company through phases of strategic expansion in the energy shipping sector. Under his leadership, Avance Gas grew from a startup to a prominent operator, leveraging long-term charter contracts to ensure stable revenue amid volatile shipping markets.[12] Key achievements during his tenure include the fleet expansion through an orderbook of eight newbuildings announced in 2014, with deliveries increasing the fleet to 14 VLGCs by the end of 2015, which enabled Avance Gas to capture a significant share of the international LPG trade, particularly in routes connecting the Middle East, Asia, and Europe. This positioning capitalized on rising global demand for LPG as a cleaner fuel alternative, with the company's vessels achieving high utilization rates and contributing to efficient supply chain logistics for petrochemical feedstocks. By 2024, Avance Gas had established itself as a leading independent owner in the VLGC segment before the sale of its fleet to BW LPG.[13][14][15] In 2024, Avance Gas sold its fleet of 12 VLGCs to BW LPG for approximately $1.05 billion, completing Stolt-Nielsen's divestment from the company.[15]

Roles in LNG and related sectors

Niels G. Stolt-Nielsen has served as a director of Golar LNG Limited since September 2015, where he contributes to the company's advancements in floating liquefied natural gas (FLNG) technology and LNG carrier operations.[5] Under his board tenure, Golar has pioneered FLNG units like the Hilli Episeyo, the world's first converted FLNG vessel, which began production off Cameroon in 2018, enhancing efficient LNG liquefaction and export capabilities. His involvement aligns with Golar's strategic expansions in modular FLNG solutions, supporting global energy supply chains.[5] As Chairman of the Board of Avenir LNG Limited since October 2018, Stolt-Nielsen has guided the company's growth in small-scale LNG distribution and infrastructure development.[2] Avenir, in which Stolt-Nielsen Limited holds a majority stake, focuses on bunkering, trucking, and regasification solutions to deliver LNG to remote and industrial markets, including investments in small-scale carriers and storage terminals.[16] His leadership has supported Avenir's growth, including the expansion of its fleet of small-scale LNG carriers, with 5 vessels in operation and additional newbuildings on order by 2023, facilitating LNG as a transitional fuel for maritime and land-based applications.[17] Stolt-Nielsen's board capacities extend to related sustainable energy initiatives, such as his past presidency of Stolt Sea Farm from 1996 to 2000, where aquaculture operations emphasized environmentally responsible practices that complement broader energy transition goals.[18] Since the 2010s, his strategic oversight across these LNG entities has promoted the adoption of cleaner fuels in shipping, including dual-fuel vessels and LNG bunkering infrastructure to reduce emissions in line with IMO regulations.[19] This work builds complementarily on his experience in gas carrier operations at Avance Gas.

Tax residency dispute

Emigration to London

In late December 2001, Niels G. Stolt-Nielsen notified Norwegian authorities of his relocation to London, England, on December 1, 2001, where he established his primary residence.[20] This move, over a year after he had become chief executive officer of Stolt-Nielsen Limited (SNL), a global shipping company headquartered in London, reflected the demands of his CEO position that required extensive international travel and oversight of operations across multiple countries.[3] The emigration was driven by professional necessities tied to SNL's worldwide activities, including frequent business engagements in the UK that necessitated a London base to facilitate efficient management and decision-making. As a result of the notification, Stolt-Nielsen ceased making tax payments to Norway, aligning his tax residency with his new circumstances in England. His lifestyle adjustments, such as maintaining a presence in London for both work and personal reasons, supported this shift away from Norwegian tax obligations.[21][22] Norwegian authorities initially accepted Stolt-Nielsen's claimed foreign residency for the tax years 2002 through 2004 due to a clerical error in processing at the Oslo tax office, which led to no Norwegian tax assessments being issued during this period. This provisional acceptance provided temporary relief from Norwegian taxation, though it stemmed from administrative oversight rather than a formal determination of residency status.[23][22]

Legal challenges and outcomes

In 2005, Norwegian tax authorities discovered a clerical error in their prior assessments of Niels G. Stolt-Nielsen's residency status, which had initially accepted his 2001 emigration notification to London for the years 2002–2004. This prompted the Oslo Tax Office to claim back taxes for the period 2001–2005, asserting that he maintained permanent residence in Frogner, Oslo, due to strong personal and familial ties to Norway.[22][23][24] Stolt-Nielsen responded by filing a lawsuit against the Norwegian Tax Administration, seeking to overturn the revised tax assessments and affirm his primary residency in London, where he conducted most of his professional and personal life. He argued that his time spent in Norway was limited and incidental, primarily for family visits and obligations, and that his center of vital interests had shifted abroad following the 2001 move.[22][25][23] In November 2007, the Oslo District Court ruled against Stolt-Nielsen on all counts, upholding the tax authorities' position that his permanent residence remained in Oslo based on factors such as ownership of a family home in Frogner, a country estate, vehicles registered in Norway, significant time spent in the country, and ongoing familial connections. The court determined that these elements demonstrated insufficient detachment from Norway to qualify as a tax emigrant, resulting in upheld tax liabilities for 2001 and 2005. Stolt-Nielsen was also ordered to cover his own legal costs of 474,000 Norwegian kroner and the state's costs of 95,000 Norwegian kroner.[22][23][26] Stolt-Nielsen appealed the decision. In December 2009, the Norwegian Supreme Court (HR-2009-2323-A) granted him partial relief by overturning the 2005 tax assessment, ruling that a declaration from UK tax authorities established his tax residency in the United Kingdom for that year under the Norway-UK tax treaty. The 2001 assessment remained upheld.[20][27]

Later developments

As of February 2023, Stolt-Nielsen relocated his tax residency from Bermuda back to Norway, citing anticipated large incomes and more favorable tax conditions in Norway compared to Bermuda.[28]

name: Uber
title: Media Buying Briefing: How the holdcos fared in 2025, according to Comvergence - Digiday
description:
Somewhat surprising is what happened in between Publicis and WPP Media.
Omnicom Media Omnicom Media really didn’t have a good year at all, which is perhaps the biggest surprise of the numbers.
Havas Media Parent company Havas has been on an acquisitive streak of late but its media arm remains smaller than its holdco counterparts.
What remains to be seen is how Havas Media fares with its new joint venture with Horizon Media.
WPP Media Sports is a new practice charged with creating sponsorships, content and integrations, with GumGum and Relo Metrics as partners.
text:
Comvergence, which hits 10 years in operation this year, has become the gold standard of measuring agencies’ success (or lack of). However, the data Digiday is citing here is only provisional. As Comvergence’s founder and CEO Olivier Gauthier explained, the data doesn’t include wins and losses not publicly announced — that final report will be issued in February, once Comvergence connects with all the agencies it tracks. (Although Gauthier acknowledges that the numbers don’t change on average more than 5% or so.)

Back to the numbers themselves. Somewhat surprising is what happened in between Publicis and WPP Media. Dentsu, it turns out, had a solid year, ending 2025 up $1.7 billion (details by holdco below), which technically puts it in second place for the year. But the gap between No.’s 1 and 2 — $9.5 billion to $1.7 billion, is cavernous to say the least.

Another surprise is third-place finisher IPG’s Mediabrands, which yielded a positive $1.6 billion, and placing it ahead of Omnicom Media, which ended 2025 up $1.2 billion — and yet Omnicom was the acquirer of IPG. If you put them together, they’d tally $2.8 billion in wins, ahead of Dentsu but still a distant second to Publicis.

Here’s a breakdown by holdco, ranked in order of total business won.

Publicis Media

It’s no secret the French holdco has been on a tear, winning Mars, Coca-Cola, Paramount, PayPal and most recently Kenvue, demolishing the competition. More importantly, it’s retained 50% of its business, according to Comvergence’s provisional totals, more than any other holdco. It lost just over $1.5 billion in media business.

Dentsu

Even though Dentsu outside of the Japanese mothership is informally on the block, it had a decent year. Although it won $1.8 billion in new business, it lost almost as much — which means its strength came from successful retention, which amounted to some $1.6 billion. Observers will be watching closely to see what happens to the former Aegis agencies that are seemingly up in the air.

IPG Mediabrands

“It’s very interesting that Mediabrands had a very good year in the U.S.,” said Gauthier. Most would agree with that sentiment, given that IPG was the acquisition target all year. It pulled in $2.4 billion in new business, but lost $1.9 billion, leaving it at a net of under $500 million — once again, successful defense helped win the day as Mediabrands held onto $1.1 billion it had to defend.

Omnicom Media

Omnicom Media really didn’t have a good year at all, which is perhaps the biggest surprise of the numbers. It’s only thanks to WPP Media’s truly awful year that distracted from this reality. Not counting retention, Omnicom Media came out just under $700 million ahead ($3 billion in wins vs. $2.3 billion in losses). To make matters worse, its retention rate was a wan 17% according to the Comvergence data, the second worse among the holdcos. It’s safe to say 2026 will be a different story as the absorption of IPG takes root — whether it’s a better or worse story remains to be seen.

Havas Media

Parent company Havas has been on an acquisitive streak of late but its media arm remains smaller than its holdco counterparts. Havas Media secured $1.4 billion in wins, lost $750 million and retained $350 million. According to Comvergence’s tallies, its retention rate was a middle-of-the-road 32%. What remains to be seen is how Havas Media fares with its new joint venture with Horizon Media. The pairing is complementary on paper, with Havas weak in the U.S. but well represented globally, and the opposite for Horizon. Gauthier said Comvergence will create a new category for that JV once it’s up and running this year.

WPP Media

And finally, WPP Media remained the punching bag of the holdcos, and with some good reason — ending the year $2 billion in the negative ($3.3 billion in wins, $6.4 billion in losses and successfully retaining only $1 billion). All that said, it’s worth noting that the Cindy Rose era of WPP was in its infancy for Q4, which is when WPP Media landed big-ticket accounts such as the U.K. government and Jaguar Land Rover (both from Omnicom). It’s also shoring up its client-side team by hiring away Angela Steele from Publicis (no easy feat to lure an exec away from the No. 1 holdco) where she had been CEO of Publicis Collective and in charge of the Verizon account. This year could bring better fortunes to the beleaguered London-based holdco.

Color by numbers

Since you’ve just had to absorb a LOT of numbers in the main story, here are two eye-popping stats that Comvergence’s Gauthier mentioned in relation to the holding companies. Together they were involved in more than 1,900 pitches across 50 countries last year, which totaled something in the neighborhood of $28 billion.

Takeoff & landing

At CES, Havas announced it will launch this spring an LLM portal called AVA, which will centralize the holdco’s access to major LLMs including GPT-5, Claude Opus 4.5, and Gemini 3.

Both WPP Media and Stagwell made moves in the sports arena. WPP Media Sports is a new practice charged with creating sponsorships, content and integrations, with GumGum and Relo Metrics as partners. And Stagwell, which has put on Sports Beach as a Cannes Lions activation for a few years, made it into its own marketing business unit, with multiple events scheduled over the course of 2026. Beth Sidhu, who is also Stagwell’s chief brand and communications officer, was named CEO.

Horizon Media said it will incorporate Sightly’s Brand Mentality and Model Context Protocol tools into its Blu market intelligence platform.

PMG acquired London and New York-based Digital Voices, an influencer marketing agency, in a bid to beef up its influencer and creator resources.

Independent Novus tapped Libby Morgan to be its new CEO, coming over from Merge where she was chief digital officer. Morgan replaces Melony Rios.

Direct quote

“71% of people say they trust people over a brand’s messaging. And they say that they trust influencers more than they would a brand’s messaging. So you have this trust thing that’s happening that’s so powerful and so important.”

Joanna O’Connell, chief intelligence officer, Omnicom Media North America, talking about the power of influencers.

Speed reading

name: Delta Airlines
title: Wow: Allegiant Air Will Acquire Sun Country in $1.5B Deal - Thrifty Traveler
description:
Allegiant said it would maintain a “significant presence” in Sun Country's Minneapolis-St. Paul (MSP) hub after the deal closes.
Sun Country CEO Jude Bricker – who worked at Allegiant before making the move to Minnesota – will only join the airline's board and serve in an advisory capacity.
In the short term, both Allegiant and Sun Country said there would be no immediate changes to upcoming Sun Country tickets, schedules, or its onboard experience.
Leaders from Sun Country and Allegiant were expected to address the proposed merger Monday morning.
Case in point: After a four-year run, Allegiant exited Minneapolis entirely just last year.
text:
Ultra-low-cost carrier Allegiant Air announced plans Sunday to acquire Minnesota’s Sun Country Airlines in a $1.5 billion transaction, swallowing up a smaller budget airline in a move that could have major ramifications for Minnesota travelers on the hunt for bargain airfare.

The proposed merger would fold Sun Country's planes, pilots, and crews all under Allegiant's umbrella, creating one bigger budget carrier – though it would still be significantly smaller than either Spirit or Frontier, according to airline data. With a deal expected to close sometime in the second half of 2026, the combined airline would continue under Allegiant's name with its headquarters in Las Vegas.

Allegiant said it would maintain a “significant presence” in Sun Country's Minneapolis-St. Paul (MSP) hub after the deal closes. But a long history of airline mergers suggests that there could be reductions in Minneapolis down the road. Sun Country CEO Jude Bricker – who worked at Allegiant before making the move to Minnesota – will only join the airline's board and serve in an advisory capacity.

In the short term, both Allegiant and Sun Country said there would be no immediate changes to upcoming Sun Country tickets, schedules, or its onboard experience. Translation? Don't worry if you're booked to fly with Sun Country in the weeks and months ahead.

The deal will require approval from President Donald Trump's Department of Justice, which has taken a friendlier approach to consolidation than the Biden administration that blocked several airline deals, including JetBlue's proposed takeover of Spirit Airlines. And unlike many previous mergers, Sun Country and Allegiant are both relatively small and barely overlap today, meaning regulators may see less cause for concern than other takeover attempts.

Leaders from Sun Country and Allegiant were expected to address the proposed merger Monday morning.

“This combination is an exciting next chapter in Allegiant and Sun Country’s shared mission in providing affordable, reliable, and convenient service from underserved communities to premier leisure destinations,” Allegiant CEO Gregory Anderson said in a written statement.

This merger is just the latest sign of turbulence in the U.S.'s low-cost carrier market, which has fallen out of favor in the post-pandemic travel boom. Spirit Airlines is in its second round of bankruptcy proceedings and yet another run of the rumor mill about an acquisition by Frontier.

Sun Country has been far more successful, posting profits for years as it challenged Delta's dominance in Minneapolis while branching out into flying packages for Amazon and ferrying college football teams and professional soccer squads across the country.

Sunday's surprise merger announcement could change everything.

What Allegiant's Acquisition Means for Minneapolis

If the merger moves ahead, it'll be the end of Sun Country in name: an airline with a storied yet often complicated brand.

Sun Country has been a household name in Minnesota for decades after starting up service in 1982 in the wake of Braniff International's collapse. After years of financial struggles operating as a beloved full-service hometown carrier, the airline began an unpopular transition to a low-cost model before the pandemic – complete with fees for everything from bags to seat assignments to buying your tickets at the airport and installed smaller seats, to boot. Its reputation took a major blow after stranding hundreds of passengers in Mexico in April 2018 … and never fully recovered.

Yet Sun Country prided itself on being a different kind of low-cost carrier. While it ripped out first class seats and shrank legroom throughout the cabin, its seating was better padded than the ultra-slimline seats that Frontier, Spirit, and even Allegiant use on their planes. Even as those competitors charged for water, Sun Country served free soft drinks and sold snacks and craft beers with a Minnesota flair.

As the rest of the budget airline industry struggled with higher costs and dipping demand after the COVID-19 pandemic, Sun Country grew fast, going public in 2021 and challenging Delta's dominance in Minneapolis. It turned the airport into what its CEO dubbed “a two-airline market.” Most importantly, Sun Country's $89 one-way fares have given Minnesota travelers a cheaper alternative to Delta's pricier fares but also forced the Atlanta-based airline to compete on price, bringing fares down across the board.

That's what could be at stake with this proposed merger. While they might both be budget airlines in name, they're drastically different in practice.

Overnight, complimentary drinks could disappear and over time, Sun Country's more comfortable seating could disappear, too. But bigger picture, the changes could be even more drastic.

When airlines buy one another, what they're really looking to buy is planes and pilots to fuel future growth. While Sun Country has been all-in on Minneapolis for decades, Allegiant focuses on operating flights between smaller airports all across the country – routes where it can have a monopoly and charge higher fares.

Even with the Sun Country name gone, Allegiant says it would maintain a significant presence in Minneapolis – it called the airport an “Important Base of Operations and Key Anchor City” in its press release announcing the merger. But what if Allegiant eventually decides to give up the fight against Delta and instead fly those planes between Las Vegas or southern Florida and other, smaller airports?

Aside from planes and people, the biggest win for Allegiant is swallowing up Sun Country's international service down to Mexico, the Caribbean, and Central America – service Allegiant has lacked. But again, what if Allegiant decides it's better to fly down to the beach from St. Petersburg (PIE) rather than Minneapolis-St. Paul?

Sun Country has relished its role as a scrappy (and cheaper) alternative to Delta. Allegiant's entire identity is built around avoiding competition altogether. Case in point: After a four-year run, Allegiant exited Minneapolis entirely just last year.

Bricker, Sun Country's CEO for nearly a decade, won't play a large role once the transaction clears. He'll join the combined carriers' board of directors but only serve in a day-to-day advisory role to Allegiant's current CEO “to help ensure a smooth and successful integration.”

Allegiant also indicated it will continue Sun Country's cargo operations on behalf of Amazon – a major upside for the Minnesota airline the last few years as travel demand has plateaued.

This is a breaking news story – check back for updates.

name: Adobe
title: Shipping Rates to Fall in 2026: Study | Supply & Demand Chain Executive
description:
The global shipping industry is entering 2026 firmly as a shipper-driven market, shaped by a widening supply–demand imbalance and easing freight rates, according to an industry outlook shared by Sarjak Container Lines.
· The global container ship orderbook currently stands at 26–28% of the existing fleet, one of the highest levels seen in more than a decade.
· Average global spot freight rates are expected to decline by up to 25% year-on-year, while long-term contract rates may fall by 8–12% as shippers regain negotiating leverage.
· Container shipping fundamentals are likely to deteriorate further due to oversupply, easing port congestion, and the potential return of vessels to Suez Canal routings, which would release additional effective capacity.
“While 2026 is expected to bring lower freight rates and improved cost visibility for shippers, the global shipping industry remains structurally fragile.
text:
The global shipping industry is entering 2026 firmly as a shipper-driven market, shaped by a widening supply–demand imbalance and easing freight rates, according to an industry outlook shared by Sarjak Container Lines.

“While freight rates are expected to normalize sharply from recent highs, the industry is unlikely to return to pre-crisis stability due to persistent geopolitical, regulatory, and environmental risks,” says Supal Shah, CEO of Sarjak Container Lines. “2026 will bring relief on rates, but not certainty. Oversupply is structural, costs are permanently higher, and volatility is now a feature, not a phase, of global shipping.”

Key takeaways:

· Global fleet capacity is projected to grow by 3.6%–5% in 2026, significantly outpacing demand growth of 1.5%–3%, according to industry forecasts.

· The global container ship orderbook currently stands at 26–28% of the existing fleet, one of the highest levels seen in more than a decade.

· Average global spot freight rates are expected to decline by up to 25% year-on-year, while long-term contract rates may fall by 8–12% as shippers regain negotiating leverage.

· Industry-wide profitability is expected to weaken materially, with several analysts forecasting losses of up to USD 10 billion in 2026, driven by falling revenues and structurally higher operating costs.

· Container shipping fundamentals are likely to deteriorate further due to oversupply, easing port congestion, and the potential return of vessels to Suez Canal routings, which would release additional effective capacity.

· The dry bulk sector is expected to remain weak but stable, with potential upside if global trade volumes recover or geopolitical tensions ease.

· A broad return to Suez Canal transits could reduce effective global vessel demand by up to 10%, as shorter voyages free up capacity.

· Rising trade protectionism, evolving U.S. tariff regimes, and shifting supply chains remain key uncertainties that could disrupt established trade lanes and dampen demand for higher-margin cargo.

· Effective Jan. 1, the EU Emissions Trading System (EU ETS) moves to 100% emissions compliance, adding permanent cost structures to Europe-linked trade lanes and accelerating cost pass-through to shippers.

· Shippers are increasingly adopting continuous rate governance, real-time pricing analytics, and AI-driven procurement tools, moving away from rigid annual contracting cycles.

· Vessel owners are prioritizing lifecycle optimization, fuel flexibility, including LNG, methanol, and biofuels, and energy-efficiency investments to meet tightening decarbonization targets while preserving asset competitiveness.

“While 2026 is expected to bring lower freight rates and improved cost visibility for shippers, the global shipping industry remains structurally fragile. Oversupply, regulatory costs, and geopolitical uncertainty will continue to define a market that is less crisis-driven, but far from stable,” says Shah.

name: L’Oréal
title: Tech: Mainstraem Brands volop aanwezig bij CES - FONK magazine
description:
Mainstraem Brands volop aanwezig bij CES Op dit moment is in Las Vegas de techbeurs CES volop aan de gang.
Alle grote tech brands zijn er vertegenwoordigd, maar er duiken steeds meer andere grote consumentenmerken op zoals IKEA, LEGO en L'Oréal.
Lego presenteert er hun nieuwe 'Smart Brick', een legosteentje, maar dan vol met technische snufjes, zoals lichtjes, sensoren voor licht, geluid en beweging en een speaker.
Ook komt Lego met nieuwe Star Wars-legosets, die de muziek en geluiden uit die films kunnen laten horen.
Ook Ikea is aanwezig met nieuwe techproducten.
text:
Mainstraem Brands volop aanwezig bij CES

Op dit moment is in Las Vegas de techbeurs CES volop aan de gang. Alle grote tech brands zijn er vertegenwoordigd, maar er duiken steeds meer andere grote consumentenmerken op zoals IKEA, LEGO en L'Oréal.

Lego presenteert er hun nieuwe 'Smart Brick', een legosteentje, maar dan vol met technische snufjes, zoals lichtjes, sensoren voor licht, geluid en beweging en een speaker. De electronica wordt aangedreven door een chip die kleiner is dan het nopje van een Legosteentje. De innovatie wordt in de vakpers inmiddels bejubeld als 'ge-wel-dig'. Ook komt Lego met nieuwe Star Wars-legosets, die de muziek en geluiden uit die films kunnen laten horen.

Ook Ikea is aanwezig met nieuwe techproducten. Het is voor het eerst dat het Zweedse bedrijf de beurs bezoekt, maar het Ikea is al langer bezig met het ontwikkelen van allerlei smart home-producten, zoals slimme stekkers, led-lampen en sensoren voor in huis. Op CES voegde het bedrijf een aantal nieuwe producten aan die collectie toe, zoals een slimme versie van de populaire 'donutlamp' Varmblixt, die ontworpen is door de Nederlandse kunstenaar Sabine Marcelis.

title: Abivax CEO Says Big Pharma Can't Ignore Its Experimental Drug - Bloomberg
description:
Connecting decision makers to a dynamic network of information, people and ideas, Bloomberg quickly and accurately delivers business and financial information, news and insight around the world Connecting decision makers to a dynamic network of information, people and ideas, Bloomberg quickly and accurately delivers business and financial information, news and insight around the world Abivax SA ’s chief executive said major pharmaceutical companies can’t ignore the potential of his firm’s experimental inflammatory bowel disease drug, as the industry looks to replace hundreds of billions of dollars in sales set to evaporate due to patent losses.
“If you are Big Pharma, you cannot ignore that this product may be one of the most-used products in the next decade,” Chief Executive Officer Marc de Garidel said in an interview in San Francisco, where drugmakers and biotech firms are convening in the city for the JPMorgan Healthcare Conference, one of the industry’s biggest meetings.

name: J&J
title: Signing Pierce Johnson continues a bullpen-focused offseason - Charlie's Chalkboard
description:
Heading into 2026, Nick Krall and the Reds’ front office made solidifying the middle relief depth in the bullpen a priority.
The deal between the Reds and Johnson was first reported by the New York Post.
The Reds’ bullpen looks pretty set right now.
Before signing Johnson, the Reds didn’t have a right-handed middle relief veteran in the mold of Barlow, Martinez, Buck Farmer or Fernando Cruz.
While the 2025 Braves weren’t good, Johnson made 45 of his 65 appearances in high-leverage spots.
text:
In 2025, as good as Emilio Pagán and Tony Santillan were in the back of the Reds’ bullpen, the middle relief core for most of the season included pitchers who weren’t incredibly consistent, guys in their first year as a relief pitcher and rookies.

Heading into 2026, Nick Krall and the Reds’ front office made solidifying the middle relief depth in the bullpen a priority. After bringing Pagán to close and signing lefty Caleb Ferguson in December, the Reds made another notable move on Sunday by agreeing to a deal with veteran reliever Pierce Johnson, according to sources.

The deal between the Reds and Johnson was first reported by the New York Post. The terms aren’t yet known.

For a while, we’ve all been wondering when the Reds would finally add that impact bat, or even replace Austin Hays and Miguel Andujar. But the front office’s focus has clearly been on the bullpen.

“We had four guys we lost in the bullpen in Pagán (re-signed), Nick Martinez, Brent Suter and Scott Barlow,” Krall said a few weeks ago. “When you look at the guys we lost, it’s something we had to continue to solidify.”

The back of the Reds’ bullpen was great last season, but the middle relief core had its rough patches.

Graham Ashcraft had a fine year as the seventh-inning guy as he made the transition to the bullpen, but he was on the injured list twice and finished the season with a 3.99 ERA. Scott Barlow was more of a workhorse than a late-game weapon. Lyon Richardson, Luis Mey and Connor Phillips got their chances to pitch high-leverage innings, and only Phillips stuck. Nick Martinez, Chase Burns and Phillips took the bullpen up a level in September, but Martinez is a free agent right now, Chase Burns is going back to the rotation and Phillips is still inexperienced.

The Reds’ bullpen looks pretty set right now. The leverage guys are Pagán, Santillan, Johnson, Ashcraft and Ferguson (the lefty). The Reds guaranteed money to Moll back in November, and it’s always good to have a second lefty. Phillips put himself in a great position to break camp with the big league club with how good he looked down the stretch last season.

That could lead to a competition for the final spot between Zach Maxwell, Luis Mey, Yosver Zulueta, Richardson (no longer on the 40-man but still in the organization) and non-roster invitees like Josh Staumont.

Before signing Johnson, the Reds didn’t have a right-handed middle relief veteran in the mold of Barlow, Martinez, Buck Farmer or Fernando Cruz. While those relievers had different levels of ability and upside, you could mostly count on them to make 60+ appearances a year. You need a certain level of stability to get you through the season and to keep you from having to regularly restock your bullpen with roster moves to provide fresh arms.

Johnson fits that mold, and he has also proven to be a capable leverage reliever on a good team.

While the 2025 Braves weren’t good, Johnson made 45 of his 65 appearances in high-leverage spots.

On a playoff team in Atlanta in 2024, Johnson was consistently a late-game option in big moments and pitched the eighth inning of a close win-or-go-home postseason game. On a 2023 Braves team that won 104 games, Johnson joined the squad at the trade deadline and quickly became a leverage guy.

It took a bit for Johnson to find his footing in MLB. But once he went all-in on his curveball (he threw more curveballs than any reliever in all of baseball last season and uses the pitch 72% of the time), Johnson leveled up.

Heading into the 2024 season, he re-signed with Atlanta on a two-year deal for $14.25 million. And then he went on to have two seasons that were as good or better than what he had done before. In 2025, Johnson posted career highs (over a full season) in ERA, WAR and many advanced metrics.

Johnson fills up the strike zone, giving the Reds a good combination of durability, reliability and late-game usefulness.

A few weeks ago, after adding outfielders JJ Bleday and Dane Myers, Krall said, “We’ve got some more money to be able to use.” Since then, the Reds freed up a bit of money by DFAing Keegan Thompson ($1.4 million) and by finalizing the salaries of most of their arbitration eligible players (by my estimation that could account for about $1 million of added financial flexibility).

Before the Johnson move, my projections had the Reds at $111 million of payroll for 2026. They were in the $116 million range last season, and 2026 payroll is expected to be pretty close to what it was last season.

A few weeks ago, when asked what the Reds could use their remaining financial flexibility to add this winter, Krall said, “Bullpen depth and some offense.”

Signing Johnson takes care of the bullpen depth. Assuming they still have a bit of financial flexibility (that will become clearer as the terms are known for Johnson), the Reds could be in the market for a first baseman or an outfielder.

In the level of free agency the Reds are working at (they’re not signing Kyle Tucker), bringing back Hays would feel like a win and a great case scenario for them.

First baseman Nathaniel Lowe, Paul Goldschmidt and Rhys Hoskins are free agents.

name: Eli Lilly
title: Eli Lilly (LLY stock): Transforming Metabolic Health While Compounding Shareholder Value
description:
The Return Case Lilly’s investment appeal rests on a powerful combination of accelerating revenue growth, operating leverage, and exceptional profitability.
The Impact Case Beyond financials, Lilly’s therapies are redefining how obesity and metabolic disease are treated globally.
Valuation in Context At first glance, Lilly’s valuation appears demanding.
Investment Thesis: Quality Growth with Real World Impact Lilly’s investment case is built on three pillars.
Over the next two to three years, earnings growth is likely to remain the dominant driver of returns.
text:
Eli Lilly (LLY stock) stands at the intersection of breakthrough medical innovation and long duration value creation. The company’s leadership in metabolic disease, anchored by its high profile weight loss and diabetes therapies, has reshaped growth expectations while delivering measurable benefits to society. With accelerating earnings, expanding margins, and a robust late stage pipeline, Lilly offers a compelling blend of return potential and real world impact that firmly qualifies it for the Good Stocks universe.

The Return Case

Lilly’s investment appeal rests on a powerful combination of accelerating revenue growth, operating leverage, and exceptional profitability. With profit growth forecast above 100 percent and industry leading margins, earnings momentum remains the central driver of long term shareholder returns.

The Impact Case

Beyond financials, Lilly’s therapies are redefining how obesity and metabolic disease are treated globally. At the same time, strong resource efficiency and high recycling rates reinforce the company’s standing as a responsible operator across its value chain.

Company Profile: A Science First Growth Engine

Eli Lilly is a global pharmaceutical leader focused on diabetes, obesity, oncology, immunology, and neuroscience. Its portfolio includes some of the most impactful medicines of the past decade, supported by deep expertise in biologics, peptide chemistry, and large scale manufacturing.

The company’s most visible products today are its GLP 1 based therapies for diabetes and weight management, which have seen unprecedented demand. These medicines address conditions that affect hundreds of millions of people worldwide and are increasingly viewed as foundational treatments rather than niche interventions.

From a market perspective, Lilly operates in therapeutic areas with durable, above average growth. Obesity treatment alone is evolving into one of the largest pharmaceutical markets globally. Lilly’s competitive moat is built on first mover scale, manufacturing capacity, strong clinical data, and a pipeline that extends well beyond its current blockbusters. This combination makes its market position defensible even as competition intensifies.

Financial Analysis: Growth Justifying the Premium

Multi Year Performance and Recent Momentum

Over the past five years, Lilly has delivered steady revenue growth that has recently accelerated sharply. Revenue growth rose from low double digits earlier in the cycle to over 30 percent in the most recent year, with trailing twelve month growth exceeding 45 percent. EBITDA and earnings growth have accelerated even more dramatically, reflecting operating leverage as volumes scale.

Margins tell the same story. EBITDA margins have expanded into the low 40 percent range, while net profit margins now exceed 30 percent on a trailing basis. Returns on equity and assets are among the highest in the pharmaceutical industry, underscoring efficient capital deployment.

Valuation in Context

At first glance, Lilly’s valuation appears demanding. The stock trades at a forward price to earnings multiple in the mid to high 40s, well above the sector average. However, valuation looks more reasonable when set against growth. Earnings per share growth is forecast above 100 percent in the near term, and revenue growth is expected to remain well above the company’s long term average.

Importantly, the growth trajectory is accelerating rather than decelerating. The step change driven by metabolic therapies has not yet fully flowed through earnings, suggesting that near term multiple compression may be offset by rapid earnings expansion.

Growth Drivers and Industry KPIs

Key industry specific indicators support this outlook. Prescription volumes for Lilly’s weight loss and diabetes drugs continue to rise, capacity expansions are coming online, and demand remains supply constrained in several markets. Unlike many pharmaceutical growth stories, this momentum is driven by real world utilization rather than pricing alone.

Analyst Expectations and Upside

Consensus analyst targets imply modest single digit upside from current levels. That may appear conservative, but it reflects the stock’s strong recent performance rather than deteriorating fundamentals. With a Ziggma Score of 88, supported by profitability at 95 and financial health at 97, Lilly remains one of the highest quality profiles in global healthcare.

Risks to the Return Scenario

The primary risks center on competition, pricing pressure, and execution. Rival therapies could narrow Lilly’s market share over time. Regulatory scrutiny around drug pricing may intensify. Manufacturing scale up must continue without disruption. Finally, expectations are high, which increases sensitivity to any earnings disappointment.

Risks to the Return Scenario

If Lilly sustains current growth rates for longer than expected, earnings expansion alone could drive meaningful upside even with stable valuation multiples.

Impact Analysis: Medicines That Change Lives

Tackling Obesity at Scale

Lilly’s weight loss therapies represent one of the most significant medical advances in decades. Obesity is linked to diabetes, cardiovascular disease, and reduced life expectancy. By enabling substantial and sustained weight loss, these drugs have the potential to reduce healthcare costs and improve quality of life for millions.

Responsible Resource Use

Beyond patient impact, Lilly scores highly on Sustainable Resource Use, with an especially strong recycling rate that drives its elevated score in this category. Efficient water use and waste management reflect disciplined operational practices that reduce environmental footprint across manufacturing sites.

Investment Thesis: Quality Growth with Real World Impact

Lilly’s investment case is built on three pillars. First, a step change in growth driven by category defining metabolic therapies. Second, best in class profitability and financial strength that allow the company to reinvest at scale. Third, tangible societal benefits that reinforce long term license to operate.

Over the next two to three years, earnings growth is likely to remain the dominant driver of returns. Even if valuation multiples normalize modestly, earnings expansion can support continued share price appreciation. Crucially, this growth is underpinned by products that deliver clear benefits to patients and healthcare systems worldwide.

LLY Is Where Innovation and Impact Reinforce Returns

Eli Lilly exemplifies what a Good Stock should look like. It pairs industry leading growth and profitability with therapies that address some of the most pressing health challenges of our time. While valuation is no longer cheap, the company’s accelerating growth trajectory, operational excellence, and profound societal impact make a compelling case for long term investors seeking both returns and purpose.

Important Notice

This article is not investment advice. We cannot predict whether the stocks mentioned in this article will go up or down.

We believe the information contained in this text to be reliable but do not warrant its accuracy or completeness. Opinions, estimates, and investment strategies and views expressed in this document constitute our judgment based on current market conditions available data and are subject to change without notice. Please consider your full financial situation prior to making an investment decision.
